challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: This foundational mitzvah calls us to treat every individual with honor, respect, and dignity. It is more than politeness; it is a commitment to recognising the divine spark within every person.
challenges.connection: Bereshit teaches that humanity was created B’tzelem Elohim—in the image of God (Genesis 1:27). Cain’s tragic failure to see this divinity in Abel warns us what happens when dignity is denied.
challenges.challenge: Identify one person you often overlook (perhaps a cashier, coworker, family member, or someone with whom you disagree) and intentionally honour their dignity this week. For example, make eye contact and sincerely thank the cashier, actively listen to a family member without interrupting, or find a point of shared humanity with a coworker. Share how the encounter changed your perspective in the mitzvah chat.

challenges.mitzvah: Tza'ar Ba'alei Chayim (Preventing Cruelty to Animals)
challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: We are commanded to treat all living creatures with compassion, preventing unnecessary suffering and caring for the natural world entrusted to us by God.
challenges.connection: In a corrupt world filled with violence, Noach is chosen to preserve life by safeguarding the animals in the ark. His righteousness expresses itself through stewardship of God’s creations.
challenges.challenge: Emulate Noach by practising kindness toward animals or the environment. For example, put out fresh water for birds, extend extra playtime or care to a pet, consciously reduce your waste for a day, or pick up trash on your street. Share how you acted as a guardian of God’s creations.

challenges.mitzvah: Gemilut Chasadim (Acts of Loving-Kindness Performed Anonymously)
challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Gemilut Chasadim invites us to perform selfless acts of kindness with no expectation of recognition. The highest form is kindness done anonymously.
challenges.connection: God commands Abraham, "Lech Lecha"—go forth to become a blessing. Abraham discovers his true self through giving, modelling a life of quiet, generous chesed.
challenges.challenge: Be a hidden blessing. Perform one act of kindness anonymously. For example, leave an encouraging note for a coworker, pay the toll for the car behind you, or secretly help a family member with a chore without seeking credit. In the chat, simply share that the challenge was completed.

challenges.mitzvah: Hachnasat Orchim (Welcoming Guests with Full Presence)
challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Hospitality means more than opening a door—it is about making guests feel fully seen, honoured, and nourished in body and spirit.
challenges.connection: Abraham pauses a divine encounter to run toward three strangers, demonstrating that welcoming guests can surpass even greeting God, for it brings the Divine Presence to others.
challenges.challenge: Welcome someone with your full presence—perhaps a guest, family member, or colleague. For example, put your phone away during dinner, ask a colleague about their day and truly listen to the answer, or make a guest feel like the most important person in the room. Share the moment in the chat.

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: This elevated level of kindness anticipates another’s needs and exceeds what is asked, offering generous support before it is requested.
challenges.connection: Rebekah exemplifies this mitzvah when she waters Eliezer and his camels without being asked, proving herself the builder of the next generation.
challenges.challenge: When someone requests a "small drink of water," respond like Rebekah—do more than what is asked. For example, if a friend asks for a ride, offer to help them with their errands too. If a coworker asks for help on one task, offer to review the whole project. Share how you "drew water for the camels."

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Practise self-control for the sake of higher ideals. Invest in long-term values rather than surrendering to fleeting gratification.
challenges.connection: Esau trades his birthright for instant satisfaction, while Jacob safeguards the legacy. The parsha urges us to honour what endures over what is momentary.
challenges.challenge: Identify one habitual quick fix and trade it for an action that invests in your legacy. For example, instead of doom-scrolling for 10 minutes, use that time to read one article on a topic you want to learn, or write a one-sentence journal entry. Share your "trade" in the chat.

challenges.mitzvah: Makom – Finding God in This Place
challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Cultivate awareness of holiness in ordinary spaces. Recognise divine presence and gratitude in the everyday moments of life.
challenges.connection: Jacob discovers a ladder to heaven while alone on rocky ground, exclaiming, "Surely God is in this place—and I did not know!".
challenges.challenge: Once a day, pause in a mundane setting—like your kitchen, your car, or your desk at work—breathe, and say, "Surely God is in this place." Name one point of gratitude right there. Share the location of your unexpected holy moment.

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Do not wait for harmony—create it. Take the first courageous step to heal a strained relationship or de-escalate a conflict.
challenges.connection: Jacob humbly approaches Esau with prayer, gifts, and vulnerability, modelling active pursuit of peace even amid fear.
challenges.challenge: Choose one tension—large or small—and send the first olive branch. For example, send a text saying 'thinking of you' to a friend you've argued with, make a coffee for a family member after a disagreement, or offer a sincere apology. Share (without details) if you took that step toward peace.

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Guarding our words prevents harm. Lashon hara—negative speech about others—is viewed as one of the most destructive behaviours.
challenges.connection: Joseph’s "bad reports" ignite jealousy that tears the family apart. The parsha warns how careless words can cause lasting damage.
challenges.challenge: Go 24 hours without speaking negatively about anyone who is not present. When tempted to join in gossip or complain about someone, pause and either remain silent or change the subject. Share the moment you noticed the challenge—or if you succeeded.

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Humility recognises our successes as gifts and channels of divine blessing. It is not self-negation, but gratitude and perspective.
challenges.connection: Joseph, newly summoned from prison, says "Bil'adai"—"It is not me"—directing Pharaoh’s praise to God. His humility elevates him.
challenges.challenge: When you receive praise, internally thank God and outwardly share credit or gratitude. For example, if praised for a project, say: 'Thank you, I couldn't have done it without [teammate]' or 'Thank you, I was glad to help.' Share how it felt to practise Bil'adai.

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Areivut calls us to become guarantors for one another, stepping up to protect, support, and advocate for someone else.
challenges.connection: Judah transforms by offering himself in Benjamin’s place, embracing responsibility and healing his family.
challenges.challenge: Find an opportunity to step in for another. For example, offer to mentor a junior colleague, help a friend move even when you're busy, or stand up for someone who isn't in the room. Share how you became an "arev" this week.

challenges.title: This Week's Mitzvah Challenge
challenges.explanation: Forgiveness is the choice to release another from the emotional debt they owe you, freeing both of you to move forward.
challenges.connection: Genesis concludes with Joseph forgiving his brothers, reframing their betrayal as part of God’s plan and choosing compassion over vengeance.
challenges.challenge: Identify one grudge—perhaps against a family member for an old argument or a driver who cut you off this morning—and consciously release it. You need not tell the other person; simply declare within yourself, "I let this go." Share "Challenge completed" in the chat to mark the act.
